appearances.snippet: joining me now from capitol hill is california congressman ted lieu.the vice chair of the house democratic caucus and sits on the foreign affairs committee. congressman, welcome to the story is for the first time. >> thank you, elex. >> do you agree with the premise of the trump administration that the u.s. controlling greenland would be good for u.s. national security >> so thank you, elex, for asking that question. sure. it will be good for u.s. national security, but it would also be illegal. denmark owns greenland, and we can't just invade a nato country. that is insane. and the president has no justification for doing so. so that is my answer. you can't just act as if there is no laws, if there's no treaties, we're part of nato. we don't threaten other countries. >> so when it came to venezuela, the president didn't ask for congress and hasn't really been held accountable by congress, at least not yet. if he wants to do this on greenland, is there anything you all can do to stop him? because it seems like he's a big fan of asking for forgiveness,

appearances.snippet: let's discuss with democratic congressman ted lieu of california. he is a member of the house foreign affairs committee and a u.s. air force veteran, where he served in the jag corps. congressman, thank you so much for being with us. i want to start on on the broader strategy here for the united states. and whether you think that the u.s. is today better positioned with nicolas maduro out of power and chinese and russian influence in the western hemisphere, potentially weakening. >> well, if you want to talk about the broader context, let's just first say that we know that health care costs are skyrocketing, food prices are increasing, electricity rates are surging. and what does trump focused on? he's focused on, in his words, quote, running the country of venezuela. that is insane. and the american people want the president to focus on what's happening in our country, not doing the bidding of oil companies. and in terms of does this make america stronger? well, we just put in maduro, vice president delcy rodriguez, she is now in charge of the coun

appearances.title: U.S. House of Representatives U.S. House of Representatives : CSPAN : January 13, 2026 1:30pm-3:39pm EST
appearances.snippet: next up, vice chair ted lieu. thank you, chairman aguilar. my prayers go out to renee goode and to her family and friends. she was a u.s. citizen, a christian and a mother of three. this tragedy was completely preventable. and i ask the federal government to cooperate with local and state officials who are doing investigations. we need to have fair and transparent investigations. and when federal officials do not cooperate with state and local officials in the investigation, and it leads american people to think, what are you hiding? are you covering something up? so for full transparency, we need everyone to cooperate to get to the bottom of what happened. and i also asked ice leaders in the administration to tone down the rhetoric. ice commander greg bovino last night made a post that essentially called protesters, quote, cannon fodder. he needs to delete that post or he needs to resign. the american people are not cannon fodder. we have absolute first amendment right to witness what ice is doing publicly to film what ice is doing publicly

appearances.title: Sen. Mark Kelly on Artificial Intelligence & Innovation : CSPAN3 : January 9, 2026 11:34pm-12:35am EST
appearances.snippet: we've seen a lot of proposals from representatives ted lieu, bill foster regarding legislation on ai and then we've also seen the trump administration try and push preemption of state ai laws in things like the ndaa and other sort of and other sort of bills as well. i'm curious what you think whether federal federal legislation on ai exists. your opinion on state preemption of ai laws, do you think that might be a good thing, bad thing? >> you mean whether it exists right now? >> should we preempt or should it be possible for the federal government to preempt state law? >> like in the event that federal legislation on ai laws exists like ted lee's proposal, do you think we should preempt? >> i think generally, you know, if you have a federal law that really, you know, really strongly addresses issues, i think the states should follow those laws. right now we don't have that, and i think it's up to the states to be able to protect their citizens in those states, you know, state legislatures and the governor, uh, when they see that there's a problem. it's, it's not only their right, it
